results.title: [ABC TV News: Bulletin for 11th March, 1958]
results.brief_description:
The first ABC TV nightly news bulletin was broadcast on 5th November, 1956. The newsreader, James Dibble, went on to present the ABC TV News in Sydney for 27 years; his last bulletin was on June 10, 1983.

When television arrived in Australia the ABC Commissioners were concerned that pictures might trivialise the news and decided that no more than two minutes of film should be included in a 15-minute bulletin. This early news bulletin (from 1958) conforms to this rather stilted style of presentation considered appropriate by the ABC. The minimal use of graphics and live news footage, as well as the newsreader’s accent, are in striking contrast to the way news and current affairs have been presented on television in the decades since the 1950s.

In this bulletin, the news includes reports of conflict between the Indonesian government and Sumatran rebels, an Australian High Court taxation law ruling, cleaning-up after a big storm in Sydney, the discovery of a World War II mass grave in Poland, elections in Sudan, and a report on the state of the international television industry in 1957.

results.title: [A New map for Canada]
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, James Beveridge, Robert Anderson and John H. Tyo
results.brief_description:
This film is a survey of Canada in terms of its national air service. Far below a Trans-Canada Airlines (T.C.A.) passenger plane, the new map, a continent wide, unrolls, patterned with high mountains and orchard valleys, prairies with their rectangular grainfields, the Great Lakes and the eastern farmlands. One T.C.A. flight soars over Cleveland and New York; another service crosses Québec and the Maritimes; while a trans-oceanic air liner heads out across the broad Atlantic.
Title and credits missing.
